The development of solid acidic catalyst is of great significance to the safe, controllable, efficient and environment-friendly nitration of aromatics. Herein, a series of trimetallic supported catalysts were obtained by the equivalent-volumetic impregnation method. In the as-prepared Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst with strong acidic sites, the metal oxide particles mainly distributed in a form of nanowires in MCM-41 molecular sieve channels. And, the Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst exhibited an excellent catalytic performance for the nitration of acetanilide with equivalent dilute nitric acid as a nitration reagent. Surprisingly, 91% conversion of acetanilide with 91.6% selectivity to mono-nitroacetanilide was achieved. The nitration of acetanilide obviously exhibited a typical ortho-para nitration effect of the aromatics. Furthermore, an excellent stability and acceptable reusability proved a potential to replace the nitration system of concentrated acid in chemical industry. The Lewis acid sites of Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 solid acid catalyst can act a similar role to a strong protic acid in mixed acid system, which can polarize nitric acid molecules to form active NO2 + reagents. Meanwhile, the abundant strong acidic sites of solid acidic Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox in MCM-41 channels are significantly conducive to the sorption and activation of the reactants. The present work provides a prospective strategy for constructing a solidic acid catalyst with an eco-friendly nitration of aromatics. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CeCuCoOx/MCM-41 catalyst Solid acidic catalysis Eco-friendly nitration Acetanilide Acidic site Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Aromatic nitro compounds can be widely used in dye, medicine and other fields [1]. Among these aromatic nitro compounds, nitroacetanilide (2(o)-nitroacetanilide, 3(m)-nitroacetanilide and 4(p)-nitroacetanilide), as an important intermediate, is used to produce 2-aminobenzothiazole derivatives [2,3], dye intermediates [4,5] and organic non-linear optical (NLO) material [6]. Due to a wide application and high economic value of nitroacetanilide, the research on its synthesis is of great significance. At present, the nitration process of nitric-sulfuric mixed acid (HNO3/H2SO4) is mainly used in the production of nitroacetanilide [7]. While this process exists many disadvantages, including corrosion of equipment by strong acid and massive exothermic reaction. Moreover, the strong acid system increases the risk of production and produces excessive waste acid that is difficult to be treated [8]. With an increasing problem of environmental pollution, the concept of green chemistry has been deeply rooted in the minds of people. The development of safe, controllable, efficient and environment-friendly preparation methods of aromatic nitro compounds has become an important strategy. In general, the formation of nitronium ions (NO2 +) is significant imporatant in concentrated acid nitration system Eq. (1). In the concentrated nitric acid system, the NO2 + can be formed by autocatalysis, which can be explained as two steps of the protonation and dehydration of HNO3 Eqs. (2) and (3). The nitration formulation of benzene and other arenes (ArH) by NO2 + can be described such a successive mechanism [9]. Under the action of NO2 +, the reactants forms π complex and then directly transforms into σ complex, followed by proton transfers to produce the substitution product. The successive mechanism can be called electrophilic substitution mechanism of aromatic hydrocarbons. In view that the water produced by the reaction will continuously reduce the content of NO2 +, the additional strong protonic acids, as concentrated sulfuric acid, are needed to promote the protonation of HNO3 (Eq. 4) [10,11]. However, in the nitration system of nitric-sulfuric mixed acid, the produced excessive waste acid is difficult to be treated. The introduction of solid acid replaces the protonation of sulfuric acid, which is considered as a green and promising strategy. (1) ArH+NO2 +→Ar-NO2+H+ (2) HNO3+HNO3→H2NO3 ++NO3 − (3) H2NO3 +→NO2 ++H2O (4) HNO3+H2SO4→H2NO3 ++HSO4 − Solid acidic catalyst is known in the form of acid-leached natural aluminosilicates, zeolites, heteropoly acids, superacid oxides and sulfated metal oxides, etc. [12] CeZrOx treated with sulfuric acid to obtain CeZrS catalyst, which achieved 34% nitration product for toluene at 90 °C and equivalent nitric acid [13]. The sulfated SO4 2−/WO3, as an eco-friendly and effective solid acid catalyst, exhibited remarkedly catalytic activity for the nitration of toluene [14]. Similarly, the SO4 2−/FeCu-ZrO2 catalyst was also found to achieve highly selective nitration of 1-nitronaphthalene in liquid phase [15]. Zeolite Hβ as a solid acid catalyst has been used, and achieved a 98% yield of 2,4-dinitrotoluene under a ratio of toluene: nitric acid: propanoic anhydride of 1: 3.4: 3.7 [16]. Ganjala et al. developed an eco-friendly nitration of benzene over zeolite-β-SBA-15 catalyst with dilute nitric acid [17]. Moreover, Cs2.5H0.5PMo12O40 with Keggin-type structure on silica support could also be used as an efficient catalyst for the nitration of benzene with nitric acid [18]. Besides, the CuCoFeOx catalyst with spinel structure, as a solid acidic catalyst, achieved a high yield of 2,4-dinitrotoluene in the nitration of benzene with 2 equivalents of 98% HNO3 [19]. Similarly, hydrophobic WO3/SiO2 catalyst exhibited activity for the nitration of aromatics with equivalent nitric acid in liquid phase [20]. Obviously, metal oxide composites as solid acid catalysts can efficiently catalyze the nitration of aromatics with equivalent nitric acid, which is eco-friendly and promising strategy to avoid the treatment of waste acid. For the solid acid catalytic nitration, the introduction of multi-component metal oxides can eliminate the use of sulfuric acid and plays a positive role in the opening up a green nitration model and the development of green chemistry. Multi-component metal oxides can not only show acidity [21], but also activate C-H, C-C and N-H bond to promote the reaction [22–25]. However, pure polymetallic oxides exhibit often acidic insufficiency and the instability of protic acids. Moreover, the dispersity of pure polymetallic oxides is inadequate to easy gather, influencing the catalytic activity. The polymetallic oxides combined with MCM-41 can effectively improve the acidity of polymetallic oxides. Meanwhile, due to the acid resistance of MCM-41, the catalyst can perform better in the stability of structure and acid site. More importantly, the introduction of MCM-41 with abundant and regular pore and channel structure can markedly increase the specific surface area to promote the adsorption performance of the polymetallic oxide catalysts, and significantly enhance the diffusion and mass transfer of reactants [26]. Therefore, the introduction of MCM-41 is an efficient strategy to enhance the catalytic activity of polymetallic oxide solid acidic catalysts for the nitration of acetanilide. Herein, by changing the metal oxide ratio and support, a series of trimetallic supported catalysts were obtained by the equivalent-volumetic impregnation method. The composition, morphology, structure, and acid site properties of the catalysts were systematically analyzed via various characterization methods. The catalytic performance was tested and evaluated by the nitration of acetanilide with equivalent dilute nitric acid as a nitration reagent. The Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst can achieve an excellent catalytic activity for the nitration of acetanilide. The stability and reusability of the Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst were explored by the XPS analysis and recycling experiments. The catalytic mechanism of electrophilic substitution by solid acid was proposed for the nitration of acetanilide. For the excellent nitration performance, the present strategy of solid acidic catalysis can be extended to the eco-friendly nitration of other aromatic compounds. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (99.0%), Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (99.0%) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99.0%) were provided by Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. MCM-41 and ZSM-5 zeolites were obtained from Nanjing XFnano CO., Ltd. Acetanilide (99.0%), 2-nitroacetanilide (99.0%), 3-nitroacetanilide (99.0%) and 4-nitroacetanilide (99.0%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent CO., Ltd. All other chemicals were purchased from commercial reagent companies. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts All catalysts were prepared by equivalent-volumetic impregnation methods. The saturated water absorption of different carriers was measured first. Typically, 0.5 g of the support was placed in a small flask, and its quality m1 was recorded. Then, deionized water was slowly added into the flask, and the quality was recorded and named as m2 when the carrier was just saturated. The volume of adsorbed water can be obtained by subtracting m1 from m2. The impregnation solution of metal oxide precursors with corresponding mass concentration was prepared under the adsorbed volume. By the ultrasonic cleaning instrument for 0.5 h, the impregnation solution was evenly loaded and absorbed on the carrier. Then, the impregnated sample was dried at 100 °C for 5 h and roasted at 500 °C to obtain the finished catalyst. In practical terms, the impregnation solution of Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst contains Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (435 mg, 1.00 mmol), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (363 mg, 1.62 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (55 mg, 0.19 mmol). For Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst, the actual amount of the trimetallic elements has been analyzed by ICP test. The actual metal ratio (Ce: Cu:Co) was determined to be approximately 4.3: 6: 0.6 (Table S1), which was basically consistent with the theoretical metal ratio. The adsorption volumes of various carriers were tested and calculated as MCM-41 (2 mL/0.5 g), ZSM-5 (1.1 mL/0.5 g), SiO2 (1.1 mL/0.5 g) and Al2O3(0.9 mL/0.5 g). The other supported catalysts were synthesized by using the corresponding amount of raw materials in a similar method. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The XRD was performed on Rigaku D/max 2500 at nickel filtered Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). The sample morphology was determined by Hitachi S-4800 SEM measured at15 mA and 20 kV. The TEM images of the samples were measured using an FEI Talos F200X electron microscope measured at 200 kV. The XPS spectra of the samples were performed using an electron spectrometer (ESCALab 220I-XL, VG Scientific) at 300 W Al-Kα radiation. The FT-IR data was determined on a VECTOR-22 spectrophotometer with a KBr pellet technique from 400 to 4000 cm−1 by the accumulation of 32 scans. The Raman spectra were tested using a Laser microscopic Raman imaging spectrometer (Thermo Fisher) with single crystal silicon as the position correction. The NH3-TPD were measured using an Autochem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics). Pyridine-IR as performed on a Fourier infrared spectrometer (TENSOR 27, Bruker) with the a CaF2 window at a resolution of 4 cm−1. The N2 adsorption/desorption curves were determined by Micromeritics ASAP 2460 instrument, and the pore size distribution were analyzed by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. 2.4 Typical procedure for nitration of acetanilide using nitric acid Typically, 5 mL of acetonitrile, 20 mg of catalyst, 0.0675 g (0.5 mmol) of acetanilide, 0.0969 g (1 mmol) of 65% nitric acid, and magnetic stirrer were successively added to a 15 mL pressure flask, sealed and reacted at 80 °C for 12 h. After the reaction, the reaction solution was transferred into a 250 mL volumetric flask, and methanol was added to the tick mark. The concentration of reactants and products in the solution were detected by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, WAYEELC 300–2 Series instrument) with an Ultimate MB-C18column (250 × 4.60 mm) at 40 °C by UV detector at the wavelength of 220 nm, and the mobile phase was consisted of the methanol/water 25/75 (V/V) solution combined with a flow-rate of 1.0 mL/min. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 characterizations of catalysts To explore the species and crystalline phase of the catalyst, the XRD patterns of the samples were studied (Fig. 1 ). The CeO2/MCM-41, CuO/MCM-41, and Co3O4/MCM-41, as single metal oxides supported catalysts, exhibit very clear diffraction characteristic peaks of the relevant metal oxides, which are consistent with the corresponding standard cards (JCPDS 34–0394, 45–0937, and 43–1003). The diffraction peak in the CeO2/MCM-41 is relatively wide, which indicates that it is in polycrystalline state [27]. The diffraction peak at 28.6, 33.1, 47.5, 56.3, 59.1, 69.4, 76.7 and 79.1° can be attributed to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331) and (420) crystal planes of CeO2 [28]. The CuO/MCM-41 and Co3O4/MCM-41 exhibit sharper diffraction peaks and good crystallinity. The diffraction peak at 32.5, 35.5, 38.7, 46.2, 48.7, 53.5, 58.3, 61.5, 65.8, 66.2, 68.1, 72.4 and 75.0° can be attributed to the (-110), (002), (111), (-112), (-202), (020), (202), (-113), (022), (-311), (-220), (311) and (004) crystal planes of face-centered cubic CuO [29]. While the diffraction peak at 19.0, 31.3, 36.8, 44.8, 59.4, and 65.2° can be belonged to the (111), (220), (311)), (400), (511) and (440) crystal planes of face-centered cubic Co3O4 [30]. However, the XRD patterns of CeO2/MCM-41, CuO/MCM-41 and Co3O4/MCM-41 exhibit merely the diffraction characteristic peaks of the corresponding metallic oxide, while the diffraction peak of MCM-41 is barely detected. These results demonstrate that the effect of MCM-41 molecular sieve on XRD characteristic peaks of supported catalysts is almost negligible, which is consistent with our previous work [31]. The diffraction peaks of CeO2, CuO and Co3O4 can be clearly observed over the XRD patterns of the Ce4Cu6Co0.5OX/MCM-41, indicating the successful formation of trimetallic oxides in the Ce4Cu6Co0.5OX/MCM-41. Among these peaks in the Ce4Cu6Co0.5OX/MCM-41, the intensity of the diffraction peak of Co3O4 is very low, ascribing to the less content of Co element. The SEM images in Fig. 2 a indicate that the morphology of the catalyst is composed of irregular lumps. The finer structure is shown in TEM images (Fig. 2b and c), which display a tubular structure of MCM-41 [32], and tiny metal oxide particles attached to the MCM-41surface. Interestingly, the STEM images exhibit a surprising finding that most of the metal oxides are in the form of nanowires, while a small part exists in granular form (Fig. 2h). These results can also be observed in the EDX mapping (Fig. 2i). The Al, Si and O elements are distributed evenly in the phase of MCM-41 support, while the Ce, Cu and Co are mainly distributed in form of the metal oxide particles attached to the molecular sieve surface and the nanowires in molecular sieve channels. It is reported that the metal can be grown s in MCM-41 tubule [33]. Meanwhile, this finding can also be confirmed by the pore size distribution results of MCM-41 and Ce4Cu6Co0.5OX/MCM-41 (Fig. S1). The pore size of MCM-41 is mainly distributed in a range of 2–4 nm, which is a typical mesoporous structure corresponding to the molecular sieve channels. When the metal oxide is loaded, the number of pores in this interval sharp decreases, which is confirmed the growth of metals in MCM-41 tubule. The growth of metal oxides in the pores of molecular sieves was further confirmed by HRTEM images. Fig. 2d exhibits the orderly arranged molecular sieve channels with a diameter of approximately 3.5 nm for the Ce4Cu6Co0.5OX/MCM-41. Moreover, Fig. 2e displays the metal oxide nanowires with a diameter of 2.0 to 2.8 nm growing along the channels. The lattice fringes of nanowires were further analyzed by HRTEM. The lattice fringe of 0.232 and 0.252 nm belongs to the (111) and (11–1) crystal planes of CuO (Fig. 2f) [34]. While, the lattice spacing of 0.244 nm can be assigned to the (311) crystal planes of Co3O4 [35]. SAED characterization in the amorphous region obtained the diffraction ring of ceria (Fig. 2g), the lattice spacing of 0.312, 0.191 and 0.163 nm corresponds to (111), (220) and (311) crystal planes of CeO2, respectively [36]. The homogenous distribution of Ce4Cu6Co0.5OX (Fig. 2i) in the MCM-41 channel benefits to enhance the catalytic property. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of MCM-41 and metal oxide catalysts with different supports are shown in Fig. S2. The MCM-41 and Ce4Cu6Co0.5OX/MCM-41 catalysts display the type IV isotherms, ascribing the typical characteristics of porosity. At low relative N2 pressure, the N2 adsorption capacity of pure MCM-4 increases slowly with an increase of pressure, which can be attributed to microporous structure of molecular sieves channels. With the P/P0 value of 0.3-0.4, the adsorption capacity of N2 increases dramatically on account of the capillary condensation in mesoporous, demonstrating the existence of mesoporous structure with the uniform pore size. Next, the change in adsorption capacity of N2 is very slight with an increase of P/P0, demonstrating that the adsorption may be close to saturation. The smaller jump of P/P0 near 0.9 comes from capillary condensation caused by pores between particles [37]. To further compare the pore structures of various types of catalysts, their specific BET surface area, pore size, and pore volume are listed and compared in Table S2. The MCM-41 possesses the highest specific surface area of 1245 m2/g. While, after loading metal oxide (Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox), the specific surface area decreases to 616 m2/g, and the pore volume is reduced from 1.10 to 0.47 cm3/g with a slightly decreased pore diameter, which indicates that metal oxides occupy the inner pores of molecular sieves to cover part of the specific surface area. The Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/SiO2 and Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/ZSM-5 exhibit also a mesoporous structure (Fig. S2), while the Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox is not a mesoporous structure, indicating that the introduction of SiO2, ZSM-5 and MCM-41 can change the microscopic pore characteristics of Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox. The order of specific surface area is Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 > Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/SiO2 > Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/Al2O3 > Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/ZSM-5 > Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox, implying that Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 may possess stronger the charge transfer rate and the adsorption for reactants. The relevant catalysts were determined by FT-IR to further observe the structure (Fig. 3 a). In MCM-41, the broad absorption band at around 3451 cm−1 belongs to the stretching vibrations of -OH, and the absorption band at 1640 cm−1 accords to the H–O–H bending vibration of H2O, which is correlated with the H2O adsorption property of the samples. The strong absorbance band at 1088 to 1237 cm−1 is ascribed to the Si-O-Si asymmetric stretching vibrations of SiO2 [38]. While the absorbance of 805 cm−1 can be assigned to the Si-O-Si symmetric stretching vibrations of SiO2, and the band of around 459 cm−1 is corresponded to bending vibration of Si-O-Si bonds [39]. The absorption band at 967 cm−1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of Si-O-Al [40]. All samples exhibit the characteristic absorption peak of MCM-41, which indicates that its composition does not changed during the preparation of the catalysts. In Co3O4/MCM-41, the absorption peaks at 668 and 583 cm−1 are assigned to the vibration modes of Co-O [41]. Except for Co3O4/MCM-41, the FT-IR spectra of other catalysts are similar to that of MCM-41. Raman spectra can confirm the existence of various metal oxides in Fig. 3b. Obviously, the MCM-41 can shield the Raman peaks of metal, which is consistent with the shielding effect of MCM-41 for Raman spectra found in our previous work [28]. For Co3O4 sample, 191, 443, and 671 cm−1 can be ascribed to F2g, Eg, and A1g modes of Co3O4 with cubic spinel structure [42]. The peak observed in CeO2 is 462 cm−1, which is consistent with the fluorite cubic ceria F2g mode [43]. For CuO, the Raman peaks at 292 and 242 cm−1 represent Ag and Bg mode [44]. The appearance of peak at 453 cm−1 in Ce4Cu6Co0.5OX may be due to the F2g mode of cubic ceria in CeCoOx solid solutions. Namely, some cobaltous oxide is doped into the lattice of ceria to form CeCoOx solid solution. The formation of solid solution shifts the peak from 462 to 453 cm−1, and makes the peak wider [45,46]. While, no obvious peak of CuO can be observed in Raman spectra of Ce4Cu6Co0.5OX, which may be ascribed to the shielding effect of CeCoOx solid solution to CuO. To study the chemical components of various elements on the catalyst surface, the fresh and used Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalysts were analyzed by XPS (Fig. 4 ). In the Ce 3d spectrum (Fig. 4a), the binding energies of 882.8, 888.8, and 898.7 eV (901.4, 907.4 and 917.3 eV) are assigned to Ce4+ 3d5/2 (Ce4+ 3d3/2), while the peaks of Ce3+ 3d5/2 (880.3 and 885.1 eV) and Ce3+ 3d3/2 (898.9 and 903.7 eV) are weaker [47]. The Ce3+ and Ce4+ ions account for 18% and 82% in the total Ce content on the surface of the Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 sample, respectively, indicating that the Ce species on the surface mainly exist in the form of Ce4+. After the nitration, the chemical states of Ce in the Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst do not change significantly, indicating the stable existence of Ce3+ species on the catalyst surface during the nitration. For the spectrum of Cu 2p (Fig. 4b), the peaks at 934.1 and 953.8 eV belong to Cu2+ 2P3/2 and Cu2+ 2p1/2, respectively [48]. For the Co 2p spectra (Fig. 4c) convolved with four peaks, the peaks at 780.1 and 795.1 eV are assigned to Co2+ 2P state, while the peaks at 781.8 and 796.8 eV are assigned to Co3+ 2P state [49]. Co and Cu elements completely present oxidation state in the composite catalyst, and there is no obvious change before and after the reaction. For the O 1 s spectrum (Fig. 4d), the peak at 530.6 eV is ascribed to the lattice oxygen, and the peak at 533.0 eV can be attributed to the surficial hydroxyl group and adsorbed oxygen [50]. Similarly, there is no significant change before and after the reaction, indicating that the metal oxide is stably combined in the MCM-41 molecular sieve channel or particle gap. This stability may be due to the electrostatic effect of oxygen rich on the oxidized metal on the surface of MCM-41. The pyridine adsorbed FT-IR spectra of the Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 a. The IR bands at 1446 and 1596 cm−1 are related to the adsorption of pyridine on Lewis acidic centers, while the band at 1490 cm−1 is attributed the interaction of pyridine adsorption with both Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites [51]. Compared with the MCM-41 without metal oxides loading in the literature, the Lewis acidity of the catalyst is greatly enhanced [52]. To quantify the acidity enhancement and explore the role of each metal oxide, NH3-TPD characterization was carried out (Fig. 5b). Three peaks of NH3 desorption are detected at approximately 250 °C (T1), 450 °C (T2) and 850 °C (T3). In general, T1, T2 and T3 can be assigned to the desorption of NH3 on weak acid sites, middle strength acid sites and strong acid sites, respectively [53]. The weak desorption peak at around 450 °C for the pure MCM-41 is slightly stronger than that for the other samples, indicating that MCM-41 exists more middle strength acid sites without metal oxides. All samples exhibit almost the same weak acid signal at around 250 °C, implying that the introduction of metal oxides has little effect on the weak acid site. For CeO2/MCM-41 samples, the strong acidity of MCM-41 is hardly enhanced after loading cerium oxide. While the strong acid sites are significantly enhanced for CuO/MCM-41 and Co3O4/MCM-41 samples compared with that of MCM-41. With an introduction of Ce4Cu6Co0.5OX, the strong acidity of MCM-41 can be also remarkably enhanced. Considering the low content of cobalt in Ce4Cu6Co0.5OX/MCM-41 catalyst, the strong Lewis acid sites may be mainly provided by CuO. Moreover, the Lew Acidity site (850 °C) of Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 exhibits the same as that of CuO/MCM-41, CoO/MCM-41, and CeO2/MCM-41 (Fig. 5b), indicating that each component may remain their original Lew Acidity as single-component. 3.2 Catalytic activities in nitration of acetanilide A series of metallic oxide supported catalysts were prepared to catalyze the nitration of acetanilide (Table 1 ). The typical reaction conditions were set as 80 °C, 5 mL acetonitrile solvent, and 2 equivalent 65% nitric acid. For the present nitration system, the nitration of acetanilide to nitroacetanilide exhibits an obvious ortho-para nitration effect of aromatic hydrocarbons. Moreover, the approximately 90% selectivity to nitroacetanilide can be almost always achieved, thus the focus of present work is mainly attention to improve the catalytic activity for the nitration of acetanilide. The blank experiment shows that the conversion of acetanilide is only 9.9 % without catalyst (entry 1). The introduction of CeO2/MCM-41 catalyst slightly increases the conversion of acetanilide (entry 2), while CuO/MCM-41 catalyst can exhibit the higher catalytic activity (entry 3). Interestingly, the introduction of CeO2 into CuO/MCM-41 was found to further improve the catalytic activity. Thus, the bimetallic supported catalysts with a different ratio of copper to cerium were constructed and evaluated for the nitration of acetanilide (entries 4–7). Among these bimetallic supported catalysts, the best catalytic effect is obtained over Ce4Cu6/MCM-41 when the ratio of copper to cerium is 6: 4 (entry 6). To further improve the conversion, different contents of cobalt oxide were introduced into the optimal Ce-Cu bimetallic oxide support catalyst (entries 8–13). After a large amount of cobalt oxide was added, the conversion decreased compared with that of Ce4Cu6/MCM-41 catalyst. While the content of cobalt oxide is gradually reduced, the conversion of acetanilide increases first and then decreases. The highest conversion is obtained when the ratio of Ce, Cu, and Co is 4: 6: 0.5. The conversion of acetanilide over Ce4Cu6Cu0.5/MCM-41 markedly increases from 75.9 to 91.0% compared with that over Ce4Cu6/MCM-41, which may be ascribed to the regulation of Ce4Cu6/MCM-41 acid sites and activity sites by cobalt oxide as a co-catalyst. To investigate the role of the support in the catalytic reaction, the catalytic activity with different supports was evaluated under the same loading (entries 14–16). For the unsupported Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox, the acetanilide conversion is merely 65% with the 87.7% selectivity to nitroacetanilide (entry 17). Obviously, the introduction of MCM-41 support can significantly promote the activity and selectivity for the nitration of acetanilide, ascribing to the dispersion of metal oxides and the adsorption of reactants by the abundant pore of MCM-41. Furthermore, the nitration activity order of supports is MCM-41 > Al2O3 > ZSM-5 > unsupported > SiO2, which may be related to the specific surface area and acidity of the sample. The order of the specific surface area is Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 > Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/SiO2 > Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/Al2O3 > Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/ZSM-5 > Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox, which is basically consistent with the catalytic activity. However, the catalytic activity of Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/SiO2 slightly decreases compared with that of Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox, ascribing that the surface acidity of SiO2 may be disadvantage to the nitration of acetanilide. Therefore, the surface acidity of molecular sieve may be a significant factor for the screening process of supports in the solid acid catalyzed reactions. The bimetallic oxide catalysts (CeCuOx, CeCoOx, CoCuOx) have also been synthesized and employed in catalytical tests (Table 1, Entries 18–20). The selectivity and activity of bimetallic oxide catalysts cannot be comparable to that of Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst. It is also worth noting that Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst can achieve an excellent catalytic activity for the nitration of aromatics compared with the reported similar systems (Table S2). The influences of acid amount, reaction temperature, reaction time, and solvent on the catalytic activity and selectivity for the nitration of acetanilide were investigated to obtain the optimal reaction conditions (Fig. 6 ). Under different acid amounts, the conversion and selectivity of the titled reaction are shown in Fig. 6a. Under 1 equivalent of 65% nitric acid, the conversion of acetanilide is merely 52.9%, ascribing to the insufficient acid amount in dilute nitric acid. When the acid amount is increased to 2 equivalents, the conversion of acetanilide reached 91.0%. As the amount of acid continues to increase, the conversion slowly continues to increase. While excessive acid leads to side reactions (e.g. polynitro byproducts) to decrease the selectivity of nitroacetanilide. Meanwhile, excessive acid also results in the problem of waste acid disposal after reaction. The nitration with low acid amount is one of the highlights of the green catalytic system. Therefore, 2 equivalents of nitric acid are more choice for the nitration of acetanilide. Fig. S3 shows the effect of catalyst amount on the selectivity and conversion of the nitration. Initially, the acetanilide conversion and nitro-acetanilide selectivity are significantly increased with an increase of catalyst amount. Under 30 mg of catalyst amount, the nitration of acetanilide can achieve the best catalytic performance. However, with a continuous increase of catalyst amount, the conversion of acetanilide decreases slowly with a decrease of selectivity, ascribing to the increase in by-products (e.g. polynitro products). The reaction temperature as a crucial factor of reaction activity was also investigated (Fig. 6b). The conversion of acetanilide is only 22.3% at the temperature of 60 °C, while the conversion reaches up to 91.0% at the temperature of 80 °C. With an increase of temperature from 80 to 100 °C, the conversion of acetanilide increases slowly with a decrease of selectivity. At the temperature of 100 °C, acetanilide is almost entirely converted, while selectivity is reduced to less than 90%. This result indicates that the by-products for the nitration of acetanilide gradually increase with an increase of temperature, which can be mainly ascribed to the formation of polynitro substitution products at high temperature. Thus, 80 °C is selected as the best reaction temperature. The reaction time is also optimized under optimal conditions (Fig. 6c). The conversion of acetanilide increases gradually with an increase of reaction time, reaching 91.0% at 12 h. No more products are obtained by prolonging the reaction time, implying 12 h is the optimal reaction time. The effect of solvent on the reaction was investigated (Fig. 6d). The highly efficient and selective nitration of acetanilide is achieved in acetonitrile solvent, while the conversion of acetanilide in tetrahydrofuran, dichloromethane and ethyl acetate solvent is very low. The nitration of acetanilide in methanol results in the alcoholysis of the products, leading to a low yield of nitroacetanilide. This result demonstrates that the solvent has a significantly effect on the nitration of acetanilide, and acetonitrile is chosen as a favorable nitration solvent. The reusability and stability of Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst was also investigated for the nitration of acetanilide (Fig. S4). The conversion of acetanilide is gradually decreased during the beginning of the three recycling tests, which may be due to the existence of a small number of unstable acid sites on the catalyst surface. Fig. S5 shows that the Lew Acidity site (850 °C) of fresh Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 is slightly stronger than that used catalyst, which conforms that a small number of acid sites on the catalyst surface are lost after the reaction. After the third recyclin experiment, the conversion of acetanilide is basically stable, implying that the Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst tends to be stable after three cycles. Interestingly, the stable surface of catalyst can partly promote the selectivity to nitroacetanilide after three recycles. Moreover, XPS spectra of the fresh and used Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 samples have no significant change (Fig. 4), which indicates that the metal oxides are stably combined with MCM-41. Therefore, the Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst can be relatively stable to be reused in the nitration of acetanilide. To explore the universality of Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst, various substrates with different substituents have been tested for the titled nitration (Table 2 ). For the aromatic reactants with para substitution (OCH3–, - CH3, - CF3, - F, - Cl, - Br, - I), high conversion of acetanilide compounds and selectivity of corresponding ortho products are achieved (entries 2–8). Especially, the conversion of p-methoxyacetanilide and p-methylacetanilide is more than 97%. For halogen substituted acetanilide, the order of conversion is -F > -Cl > -I > -Br, while the order of selectivity is -F > -I > -Br > -Cl (entries 5–8). Moreover, p-trifluoromethylacetanilide also exhibits a high conversion (entry 4), which indicates that the reaction activity has little correlation with the push-pull electron effect of substituents. The nitration products of 2-chloroacetanilide and 2-methylacetanilide are mainly in para position, and the conversion and selectivity are relatively high (entries 1 and 9). When the acetyl group is replaced by propionyl group, a high conversion can be obtained (entry 12). While the acetyl group is substituted by p-methylbenzene sulfonyl group or trifluoroacetyl group (entries 10 and 13), the conversion and selectivity are relatively low, and the main product is still para-nitro product. Alternatively, the methyl group replaces the nitrogen-attached hydrogen on acetylaniline, the conversion of such substrate is very low, which indicates that the nitration process may be related to the lone pair electrons of aniline N. The present approach can be extended to various aromatic substrates, which is expected to achieve the green and eco-friendly nitration of aromatic compounds in chemical industry. 3.3 Catalytic mechanism Based on the results of catalytic activation and characterization, a possible mechanism of acetanilide nitration over Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst was proposed (Fig. 7 ). The nanowires of cerium, copper and cobalt oxides are dispersed in the channels of MCM-41, which makes obvious strong acidity on the surface of the MCM-41 molecular sieve. Generally, nitric acid molecules are easy to be polarized under the action of strong acid catalysis [10,54]. It is worth noting that acetonitrile solvent is also conducive to the polarization of nitric acid molecules. In the process of nitration, nitric acid molecules are polarized and then dissociated into negative OH− groups and active NO2 + groups (active nitration reagents), and NO2 + attacks the conjugate unsaturated aromatic ring, resulting in the electrophilic substitution reaction. Meanwhile, the H+ substituted by NO2 + combines with OH− to form H2O, which causes the acid sites of the solid acidic catalyst to be released, thus ensuring the catalytic activity. Due to the mass transfer effect of molecular sieve channels, the product can diffuse quickly to continue the reaction. The main products are 2(o)-nitroacetanilide and 4(p)-nitroacetanilide, which also proves that the nitration mechanism is the typical electrophilic substitution mechanism of aromatics [54]. In view that the NO2 + is confirmed as a highly active nitration reagent [55,56], the production of NO2 + by Lewis acid sites on the solid acidic catalyst may be a rate-determining step for the nitration of acetanilide. While, the adsorption of HNO3 by the solid acidic catalyst is a prerequisite for the formation of NO2 +. The abundant pores and channels of MCM-41 provide a large number of special active surfaces. Meanwhile, the abundant strong acidic sites of Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox solid acid in MCM-41 channels are significantly conducive to the sorption and activate the reactants, which leads to the excellent catalytic activity of the Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41. 4 Conclusions In summary, the present work constructs a series of trimetallic oxide supported catalysts to apply for the eco-friendly nitration of acetanilide with equivalent dilute nitric acid as a nitration reagent. By changing the metal oxide ratio and support to establish the Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 with strong acidic sites, the metal oxide particles mainly distributed in the form of nanowires in MCM-41 molecular sieve channels. The Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst exhibits an excellent catalytic activity for the nitration of acetanilide with equivalent 65% nitric acid, which can achieve acetanilide conversion of 91% with 91.6% selectivity to nitroacetanilide. Moreover, the Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst also possesses an excellent stability and acceptable reusability, which is the potential to replace the nitration system of concentrated acid in chemical industry. The nitration mechanism is accord with the electrophilic substitution mechanism of aromatic hydrocarbons. The Lewis acid sites of Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 solid acid catalyst play the role of strong protic acid in the traditional mixed acid system, resulting that nitric acid molecules are polarized to form active NO2 + reagents. Meanwhile, the abundant strong acidic sites of solid acidic Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox in MCM-41 channels are significantly conducive to the sorption and activation the reactants. The present protocol provides a prospective strategy for designing solid acidic catalyst with a green and efficient nitration of aromatics. coredata.dc:description: The development of solid acidic catalyst is of great significance to the safe, controllable, efficient and environment-friendly nitration of aromatics. Herein, a series of trimetallic supported catalysts were obtained by the equivalent-volumetic impregnation method. In the as-prepared Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst with strong acidic sites, the metal oxide particles mainly distributed in a form of nanowires in MCM-41 molecular sieve channels. And, the Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 catalyst exhibited an excellent catalytic performance for the nitration of acetanilide with equivalent dilute nitric acid as a nitration reagent. Surprisingly, 91% conversion of acetanilide with 91.6% selectivity to mono-nitroacetanilide was achieved. The nitration of acetanilide obviously exhibited a typical ortho-para nitration effect of the aromatics. Furthermore, an excellent stability and acceptable reusability proved a potential to replace the nitration system of concentrated acid in chemical industry. The Lewis acid sites of Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox/MCM-41 solid acid catalyst can act a similar role to a strong protic acid in mixed acid system, which can polarize nitric acid molecules to form active NO2 + reagents. Meanwhile, the abundant strong acidic sites of solid acidic Ce4Cu6Co0.5Ox in MCM-41 channels are significantly conducive to the sorption and activation of the reactants. The present work provides a prospective strategy for constructing a solidic acid catalyst with an eco-friendly nitration of aromatics.
coredata.dc:title: Eco-friendly nitration of acetanilide over MCM-41-supported CeCuCoOx catalyst: A solid acidic catalysis strategy
